Many, many years ago I read The Invincible (Polish: Niezwyciężony) a science fiction novel by Polish writer Stanisław Lem, published in 1964.
Story line: An interstellar space ship called Invincible lands on planet Regis III, which seems uninhabited, to investigate the loss of her sister ship, Condor. During the investigation, the crew finds evidence of a form of quasi-life, born from the evolution of autonomous, self-replicating machines, who millennia ago killed off their creators.

Perhaps we should be paying attention?
Revelation 9?

context: Most people would find this exciting, and it is; that is until artificial intelligence (AI) is deployed in mass fashion. That will be frightening as a scenario such as I-Robot could become a reality. I read a piece years ago about AI. The code back then was to the point where it could "re-create" itself. What that means is that the programming behind the AI, created a "child", which was a version of itself that it wrote without any human intervention. And somewhere around the tenth generation of the code, the scientists were doing some testing whereby the different versions were competing in some type of scenario and had to take turns while doing so. I don't rememeber the exact details, but suffice it to say that one of the "child versions" near the 10th generation started cheating. It learned to look out for its own "best intertest" and began cheating in the scenario being tested. Now imagine a few thousand or millions of "child programs" and what they might do. IE take over the human race or God knows what else. For me the worse case sceneia would be one the robots with the AI deciding it's a "Democrat". Me personally? I think the version that "cheated" was the first democrat on the upcoming robot world. May God help us, we'll need it.

1 question : HOW are these powered and charged ? WATT-up, perhaps.

A swarm of microbot drones and the womens' dorms.  Yeah, that's what I'm talking about.

replies.context: Nonsense! I was a defense contractor. Uncle Sam would often spec projects  at the present limit of technology with the idea tech in all areas would increase many fold by the time the project was delivered. Only to paint themselves into a corner when the laws of science refused to budge.

You operate in the assumption that your partiuclar program area was the most cutting edge at the time. Additionally, the programs people participate in are defined by their clearance level. That said, eveything's always on a "need to know basis." And as you said, you worked for "a" defense contractor and there are many. Therefore you were not aware of every defense project out there, and if you claim you were, then I'm sorry but I don't believe you.
The flaw in your argument is that we won the contract; and wouldn't have if your argument held.
